sub_title: Award-winning Materials Scientist, Assistant Professor and Thought Leader who leverages expertise to deliver strategic leadership and industry-leading 3D Printing solutions.
summary:
I am a highly experienced Materials Scientist and Assistant Professor for the Department of Design Production at the University of Twente. I have proven skills and strengths in working with industry stakeholder teams and external agencies to develop industry-disrupting products. I combine this with a consistent record of driving quality improvements to operational processes within the 3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing spaces. 

As a skilled 3D Printing thought leader, I have in-depth expertise across the manufacturing and regulatory field and use these skills to deliver quality assurance benchmarks. Motivated and focused, with a keen appreciation of the needs of industry, management, and partner agencies, I have a proven track record in establishing professional relationships, negotiating with internal and external stakeholders and deliver product development objectives within highly regulated environments.

I am skilled in client engagement and project management, successfully working with public, private, and academic organisations. Here, I deliver increases in consciousness on key areas of sustainability to ensure effective adaptation and deliver manufacturing transformation for global companies. I also advise industry partners on Material & Process Development, Certification, and AM Design. 

While I thrive on maximising contribution through inspection and compliance best practice, I am very personable and easily facilitate clear communication with multiple teams. I believe that this is a critical aspect to delivering the high levels of quality and innovation demanded by the 3D Printing industry.

awards.title: Best Innovative Research Value Award
awards.description:
Poster award at the annual M2i conference 2019. Topic: Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing of Large, Functionally Graded Metal Components: Compositionally-graded structures by multi-wire feeding.
This research demonstrated that the great value of WAAM can be unlocked by using multiple materials in the same component during printing, and these materials can be even modified during production, by using multiple wires.

awards.title: Guinness Book of Records
awards.description: The WAAMPeller, the world’s first 3D printed propeller, was included in the Guinness Book of records, in the category of Science and Technology, page 176.

awards.description: The highest award for seniors combining excellent academic performance in all school years, together with leading presence in the school’s community. Awarded among 120 seniors.

contributors.headline: Award-winning Materials Scientist, Assistant Professor and Thought Leader who leverages expertise to deliver strategic leadership and industry-leading 3D Printing solutions.

projects.title: The WAAMPeller, The world's first 3d Printed ship's propeller
projects.description:
3D printing is a great way to produce quickly and effectively, and the relatively new technique is slowly seeping through in all kinds of fields. RAMLAB (Rotterdam Additive Manufacturing LAB), in collaboration with various organisations, has created the WAAMpeller, the world’s first 3D printed ship’s propeller for the maritime sector.
RAMLAB is the first field lab with 3D metal printers that focuses on the maritime industry. The prototype propeller is 1,350 mm in diameter, made from a nickel aluminium bronze alloy, and weighs about 400 kilograms (882 pounds).
The goal of the project is to build more efficient, cost efficient, and environmentally friendly ships. 3D printing is a great medium for that, as it uses the minimum amount of material required and works mostly autonomously.
Because 3D printed materials are built up layer by layer, they display different physical properties in different directions: a characteristic known as anisotropy. Steel or casted materials, on the other hand, are isotropic: they have the same properties in all directions. Because of this critical difference, one of the first steps was to carry out extensive testing of the material properties of the printed material.
The printing of the propeller was rather complex, as the propeller has a double-curved, geometric shape with some tricky overhanging sections. But with additive manufacturing, you can print most metallic components, so there is a lot of potential for the future.
This first prototype WAAMpeller will be used for display purposes, and planning for a second example is already underway, which the team aims to install later this year.
The collaboration of companies working on the propellers consists of Damen Shipyards Group, RAMLAB, Promarin, Autodesk and Bureau Veritas.
Aside from the huge WAAMpeller, RAMLAB also 3D prints smaller ship’s propellers from stainless steel.

source: WAAMPELLER IS THE WORLD’S FIRST 3D PRINTED SHIP’S PROPELLER - www.materialdistrict.com

Award-winning Materials Scientist, Assistant Professor and Thought Leader who leverages expertise to deliver strategic leadership and industry-leading 3D Printing solutions.
Mechanical Engineer at ELVAL SA, PhD

profile_positions.description:
Research 
Delivering thought leadership on areas surrounding multi-material 3D printing and associated novel materials, I am the Chair of Design Engineering Research at the Department of Design Production and Management. This is a key component with the Dutch government’s "Academic excellence to create impact for society (sector plan Engineering).”
Working with industry partners, I research multi-material Additive Manufacturing. Here, I research combinations of different alloys via Direct Energy Deposition, Ceramic + metal 3D printing via DLP process, multi-material 3D printing for Tissue Engineering Applications (extrusion and stereolithography based, hydrogels, metals, photopolymers). 
Overseeing multiple industrial research projects on advanced manufacturing and digitalisation, in English and Dutch, I work with an Advisor on 3D metal printing and materials research as well as being a Co-Supervisor of Ph.D. Candidates. 
I am a consultant on Additive Manufacturing for the Fraunhofer Project Centre, overseeing industrial research projects of high Technology Readiness Level (TRL). I also drive innovation across Fraunhofer Platform, I am an editorial board member of InnovatieNu magazine.
Business / Proposal Development
I have initiated six new AM research consortia in three years, driving industry innovation and change at national and European level. Here, I prepare proposals and lead on negotiations as well as identifying potential synergies and partnerships. 
Lecturing
Securing outstanding educational outcomes for students, I teach “Materials Science 1”, “Materials and Manufacturing Processes” (BSc Mechanical Engineering) and “3D Printing - Processes and Use” (MSc Industrial Design Engineering). I am also the Project Leader on "3D printed Gradient Cellular Architectures for Tissue Engineering Applications" and the Scientific Project Coordinator and Work Package Leader on "Highly Precise, 3D Printed Functional Metal-ceramic Products for Electric Motor Applications."
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: Leveraging my expertise, I advise international manufacturing clients on business development in 3D printing and consulting on publicly funded research projects (national and EU) as well as providing consultancy on materials processing, including heat treatments, welding, and additive manufacturing. Here, I develop cohesive client relationships to raise consciousness and understanding within client companies on innovations within 3D printing and their successful business application. I also maximise knowledge sharing through developing and delivering workshops and training programmes for client teams.
profile_positions.title: Consultant

profile_positions.description: Providing advisory on the planning and implementation of scientific and operational activities, I work within the Horizon 2020 “Grade2XL” Programme as well as advising on other topics of scientific interest. Here, I deliver effective leadership as a Product Owner, successfully developing and delivering eight end user demonstrators to outline product benefits to EU commission and other guests. I am also Fieldlab’s representative on the programme steering committee and technical task forces as well as the appointed work package leader on process development and demonstration.
profile_positions.title: Scientific Advisor

profile_positions.description:
Managing a self-defined research project entitled “Functionally Graded Materials by Wire and Arc Additive Manufacturing.”, I worked with RAMLAB, on a project that was funded by the Dutch government. Here, I developed strong research outcomes, including leading welding spine and additive manufacturing group’s activities using the project to develop the foundation of RAMLAB’s success in producing high quality, certified metal parts. I also performed exploratory research on multi-material WAAM, with the findings being used as a foundation for the Grade2XL (Horizon 2020) programme.
Overseeing end-to-end project lifecycles, I developed a robust hypothesis and authored a winning proposal as well as delivering research, analysis and guidance on real-world applications. These findings have been published in numerous scientific journal papers and I have also presented my findings at international conferences. 
Coaching and mentoring 10 master’s students, I ensured each student realised their potential and made useful contributions to their field of study. I also facilitated the knowledge transfer between researchers of the Aim2XL research programme and the main industrial partner, RAMLAB.
Summary:
The GradWAAM project explored the possibility of creating large-scale structural components with functionally graded metallurgical and mechanical properties by Wire + Arc Additive Manufacturing (WAAM). Using Additive Manufacturing enables the production of products-on-demand, delivering reduced time to market, reduced waste material and a lower carbon footprint. 
Additively manufactured metal components are produced by the deposition of liquid metal to a near net shape. This provides the unique opportunity to tailor the local process conditions and even alter the chemical composition locally in the weld pool to induce specific desired properties. Using graded functionality leads to revolutionary product design and improvements in the service performance of structural components.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Shaping R&D strategy and management, I established and grew an R&D team of junior engineers and researchers to lead academic-industrial collaborative research projects that focused on materials. Preparing a series of research proposals with successful outcomes at regional, national, and EU levels, I gained funding through various national and EU financing mechanisms. 

Working with 30 companies, I accelerated the development of large-scale 3D metal printing in a Start-Up Environment. Here, I established material evaluation methods and processes together with Bureau Veritas for the certification of the WAAMPeller, the world's first 3D printed Propeller, which went on to receiving a listing in the 2019 Guinness book of Records. I also represented the company at a variety of events (Holland High Tech), trade fairs (Hannover Messe) and at international conferences (International Institute of Welding) as well as being invited as a keynote speaker at TMS 2019 in San Antonio, USA.
profile_positions.title: R&D Lead

profile_positions.description:
Overseeing a PhD research project entitled "Switching from Martensitic to Bainitic Microstructure in Medium Carbon Spring Steels", I collaborated with VDL Weweler, an Dutch spring maker and OEM automotive supplier of suspension systems. Here, I developed a new heat treatment approach for producing trailing arms resulting in higher mechanical performance, cost reduction via energy consumption reduction and different alloying, successfully delivering a 30% saving in energy costs while delivering the same performance. 

My research also resulted in the company adopting self-developed processing strategy for their future product line, including aligning manufacturing with the new framework for alloy design optimisation.
profile_positions.title: PhD Researcher

profile_positions.description: Fatigue behaviour of bainitic, quenched and tempered and shot peened medium carbon spring steels. Residual stresses measurement with hole drilling technique.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate

profile_positions.description: Playing a key role in researching steel processes, products, and physical metallurgy division, I performed the statistical analysis of production and performance of plate and bar steel products. Here, I provided technical assistance and performed detailed failure analysis to Viohalco Group manufacturing plants in Greece, North Macedonia, Bulgaria, and the UK, presenting findings to technical senior leadership teams.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description: Team leader of a team of four to carry out the population census in Maroussi, Attiki, Greece in a sector of around 650 households.
profile_positions.title: Regional Coordinator
